title: Review: Lame Deer – Disguise EP
content:
Self-described as “shoe-gaze guitars and post-punk vibes, mixed with a disco love for ghost house and electronica”, it’s fair to say that UK four piece Lame Deer possess an eclectic range of influences. Signalling out two of my favourite artists as inspirations in the form of Joy Division and My Bloody Valentine, it would be all to easy for me to get on my high horse and be overtly critical, or even write them off as mere wannabes, yet in truth, Lame Deer have something rather special going on.

On their newly released five track EP entitled Disguise, they tear through pioneered sounds of the aforementioned artists in visionary style, swinging from the sublime The White Tiger to the more reserved, thrillingly addictive Cheap Hollywood. Whilst the rest of the UK indie scene appear content with sidling nonchalantly down the middle of the road, Lame Deer deconstruct and rebuild their own sound with apparent ease.

Almost impossible to pin down, the likes of Cheap Hollywood traverse the boundaries of Queens of the Stoneage-esque riffs and muddled shoegaze walls of sound. At the epicentre of Lame Deer is a stellar, no frills attached songwriting ability, whether it’s the Gorillaz vocals of The White Tiger or the emotional wreck of Good Shoes. Cold Night, the founding pillar is years of experience and a lack of inhibition. Stream my personal highlights below, and grab the full Disguise EP from their bandcamp on a pay what you like basis.
